subject: RE: [junit] How can i test a geter or seter?
msgSnippet: USUALLY being the key word... BTW: This is Lessons Learned , compiled by Don Wells, a programmer for whom I have great respect!  Nevertheless, I asked you
messageBody:
"USUALLY" being the key word... BTW: This is "Lessons Learned", compiled by Don
Wells, a programmer for whom I have great respect! Nevertheless, I asked you
to show me where Kent ever said this. And I said that even if you could show
me, I would go on testing the trivial. I have seen too many times when someone
would come behind and break the trivial in XP. Since we all own the code,
anyone has the right to bungle. I write tests to insulate me from that.

-jason

--- Patrick McGovern <themysterytramp@...> wrote:
> http://www.extremeprogramming.org/rules/unittests.html
>
> second to last sentence in the first paragraph
> --- Jason Rogers <jacaetev@...> wrote:
> > Show me where Kent ever said "don't test the
> > trivial."
> >
> > BTW: If you can do that, I still will test the
> > trivial! Just my opinion...
> >
> > -jason
> >
> > --- Patrick McGovern <themysterytramp@...>
> > wrote:
> > > hey, he asked a question.
> > >
> > > however more seriously, I believe the XP tenets
> > are
> > > pretty clear on the testing of trivial methods
> > like
> > > this getter...we just dont bother...testing the
> > > "internal state" as suggested in another email in
> > this
> > > thread would not be an explicit test of this
> > getter
> > > but a test of the functions that leave the object
> > in
> > > the tested state. It would be an implicit
> > test..which
> > > is cool:)
> > >
> > >
> > > Pax Vobiscum;)
> > >
> > > --- "STRAYER, JON (AIT)" <jon.strayer@...>
> > wrote:
> > > > You need a test case for that?
> > > >
> > > > > -----Original Message-----
> > > > > From: Patrick McGovern
> > > > [mailto:themysterytramp@...]
> > > > > Sent: Friday, December 21, 2001 1:20 PM
> > > > > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > > > > Subject: RE: [junit] How can i test a geter or
> > > > seter?
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > > would the fact that it won't compile be the
> > > > answer?
> > > > > --- "STRAYER, JON (AIT)" <jon.strayer@...>
> > > > wrote:
> > > > > > What could go wrong with this getter that is
> > > > worth a
> > > > > > test?
> > > > > >
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > class A {
> > > > > > > private int i;
> > > > > > > getI(){
> > > > > > > return i;
> > > > > > > }
> > > > > > > }
> > > > > > >
> > > > > > > I want test the geter,should i make
> > testcase
> > > > as a
> > > > > > inner class?
> > > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > >
